instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.

threads.title: Recurring problem, blinking green magsafe, does not turn on.
threads.message:
So the powerails are ok. But when I look om =<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> or DCIN or any other rail,  I see a strange recurring pulse. See picture attached of <SIGNAL>PP18V5_DCIN_CONN</SIGNAL> power rail. it is on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, but I have had this problem on other boards to 3115,2915 ect . Sometimes it solves it self, other times not, I have measured the current sensing resistors around <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> (<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>) and they are up to spec. It does not seem like its the power rails it self that does this. Is this some kind of SMC thing or what is this ? 
Could be nice if anyone else have had this problem to and knows how to solve it.

threads.title: Recurring problem, blinking green magsafe, does not turn on.
threads.message: Is the board working? Was this liquid?

threads.title: Recurring problem, blinking green magsafe, does not turn on.
threads.message: No, its not turning on. green light on the magsafe (blinking). It may have has some water damage but it has been ultrasoniced

threads.title: Recurring problem, blinking green magsafe, does not turn on.
Recurring problem, blinking green magsafe, does not turn on.
threads.message: same thing as on the picture. But they are there.

threads.title: Recurring problem, blinking green magsafe, does not turn on.
threads.message:
So it is power cycling. The usual suspects are clock chip, <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> (on airs), resistors in SPI lines to ROM. Could also be 100 other things why it is doing that. 4924 many times have shorted CPU cause of liquid on CPU Vcore regulator.
Find the corrosion and you will find the problem.

threads.title: Recurring problem, blinking green magsafe, does not turn on.
threads.message: Ok will take a look on the Clock signals and the SPI-ROM lines.
